content: quote: U.S. Seeks Expanded Power to Seize Firms Goal Is to Limit Risk to Broader Economy By Binyamin Appelbaum and David Cho Washington Post Staff Writers Tuesday, March 24, 2009 The Obama administration is considering asking Congress to give the Treasury secretary unprecedented powers to initiate the seizure of non-bank financial companies, such as large insurers, investment firms and hedge funds, whose collapse would damage the broader economy, according to an administration document. The government at present has the authority to seize only banks. Giving the Treasury secretary authority over a broader range of companies would mark a significant shift from the existing model of financial regulation, which relies on independent agencies that are shielded from the political process. The Treasury secretary, a member of the president's Cabinet, would exercise the new powers in consultation with the White House, the Federal Reserve and other regulators, according to the document. The administration plans to send legislation to Capitol Hill this week. Sources cautioned that the details, including the Treasury's role, are still in flux. <much more> "http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/23/AR2009032302830_pf.html"

Defense is not one of them; there is no better way to defend the nation. I, too, look back on time in the service and take great pride in what we accomplished. I remain doubtful that there are many more better examples of substantive, effective cultural change of large organizations as occurred for the Army (other branches, too, I expect) from 1974-1990. And the main reason it happened was effective leadership. Obviously, the funding from the Reagan buildup mattered. But the Army was changing for the better despite disastrous Jimmy Carter, who screwed its funding and turned the 101st into a NMC-rated division by '79, and that was in the midst of the Iranian hostage mess, when the 101st was part of the RDF. Those who contributed to winning the Cold War by being so good at their jobs that the scumbag communists refused to attack us can remain proud of that great accomplishment. Money alone would not have accomplished that; throwing money at problems never does solve the issues and can even impede improvement. The various federal agencies and offices that are extraneous, that would hardly be missed by the overwhelming majority of Americans if immediately abolished, may well be staffed by fine people. But the structural interactions and functions of too many of the federal agencies are excessively intrusive and spend most of their time delaying and impeding actions and resolving internal, bureaucratic conflicts, not much helping typical citizens for the gross amounts of tax money sucked up by them. Never forget that about 25% of the money sent to DC stays in DC or with its assorted agencies, just to fund the G&A costs. Absurd, and heavily non-competitive with the private sector's lower costs. It is those many offices that demand abolition, but Obama wants them bigger, thus to exact more from the private sector, since his power and control over Americans thereby increases. And there, whether it's Obama or Geithner or any of the other obamanoids, lurks the danger.

content: quote: Originally posted by GunnyRet03: quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: quote: The bottom line is government does almost nothing well..nothing. After having spent 20 years in the military, you have no idea how much I resent that remark. what a surprise It's true. See the almost nothing. I would suggest that the only thing the govt hasn't f'd up is the military we dont have b-crats running it. Too much of what guvmint is now supposed to do, it does poorly. Defense is not one of them; there is no better way to defend the nation. I, too, look back on time in the service and take great pride in what we accomplished. I remain doubtful that there are many more better examples of substantive, effective cultural change of large organizations as occurred for the Army (other branches, too, I expect) from 1974-1990. And the main reason it happened was effective leadership. Obviously, the funding from the Reagan buildup mattered. But the Army was changing for the better despite disastrous Jimmy Carter, who screwed its funding and turned the 101st into a NMC-rated division by '79, and that was in the midst of the Iranian hostage mess, when the 101st was part of the RDF. Those who contributed to winning the Cold War by being so good at their jobs that the scumbag communists refused to attack us can remain proud of that great accomplishment. Money alone would not have accomplished that; throwing money at problems never does solve the issues and can even impede improvement. The various federal agencies and offices that are extraneous, that would hardly be missed by the overwhelming majority of Americans if immediately abolished, may well be staffed by fine people. But the structural interactions and functions of too many of the federal agencies are excessively intrusive and spend most of their time delaying and impeding actions and resolving internal, bureaucratic conflicts, not much helping typical citizens for the gross amounts of tax money sucked up by them. Never forget that about 25% of the money sent to DC stays in DC or with its assorted agencies, just to fund the G&A costs. Absurd, and heavily non-competitive with the private sector's lower costs. It is those many offices that demand abolition, but Obama wants them bigger, thus to exact more from the private sector, since his power and control over Americans thereby increases. And there, whether it's Obama or Geithner or any of the other obamanoids, lurks the danger.
